title: Review: Mood Indigo – People EP
content:
Having announced his arrival on the scene with the gorgeous instrumental Dive, a really vivid, Gold Panda-esque number, fusing 80’s hip-hop vibes with more modern production elements, it served as a fitting, if not slightly mystical introduction to the music of the Boston beatmaker. Now, with his debut EP, People available, it appears Mood Indigo is spreading his wings, and unveiling more of his characteristics and personality, most notably through the addition of his own vocals.

Opening with the bizarrely disjointed yet wonderfully colourful Bird Nest, People EP is a worthwhile foray into the music of Mood Indigo, showcasing a more pop orientated side to the artist than found on Dive. Largely due to the inclusion of vocals, the pronounced hip-hop beats lend themselves to the usage of headphones, especially on Sun Brother, a delicate if not desolate track, based around the sampling of an 80’s style soul song. Personal favourite Blue Spring is one of the most deliciously textured pop songs you’re likely to hear this year, wrapped up nicely with a stunning set of Midi percussion. People may not quite be the debut release we expected from Mood Indigo, however it’s an intriguing composition and certainly marks the Boston musician out as a one for the future.
